Open table in a new tab The affinities of γ(α-βS508) and (α-βS508)(γ-βS481) channels were lower, with K i of 4.3 ± 0.2 and 5.5 ± 0.4 μm, respectively (Table II). Ion selectivity and single channel conductance were also affected by the M2 subunit composition. The conductance and selectivities for Na+ and Li+ were determined by the ratio of unitary currents in the presence of a 150 mm concentration of each one of the cations in the pipette solution (ILi+/Na+). When the magnitude of the unitary currents was too small to be measured accurately, the ILi+/Na+ratio was calculated from whole-cell currents in the presence of 150 mm Na+ or Li+ in the bath solution. All channels were also examined for permeability to K+using bath solutions containing 150 mm K+. We have previously shown that subunit composition affects the selectivity of ENaC. For instance, channels formed by α, β, and γ subunits are highly selective for Na+ over K+(Na+/K+ ratio of 1:0.001) and slightly more permeable to Li+ than to Na+(Li+/Na+ ratio of 1.5:1). αγ channels also exhibit Li+/Na+ permeabilities of 1.5:1, whereas αβ channels show Li+/Na+permeabilities of 1:1 (13Fyfe G.K. Canessa C.M. J. Gen. Physiol. 1998; 112: 423-432Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). All the functional chimeric channels conducted in the presence of Na+ or Li+ but none in the presence of K+. α(γ-βS481) and α(γ-βG529) channels were equally permeable to both cations (ILi+/Na+of 1:1). α(γ-βL535) and α(γ-βE540) channels were more permeable to Li+ with ILi+/Na+of 1.2:1 and 1.4:1, respectively (Fig. 7and Table II). Differences in the ILi+/Na+ were due mainly to a decreases in the Na+ conductance from 4.7 to 3.7 picosiemens with little change in the Li+ conductance, which remained close to 5 picosiemens for all α(γ-β) channels. γ(α-βS508) and (α-βS508)(γ-βS481) channels were more permeable to Na+ than to Li+; the ILi+/Na+ratios were smaller, 0.6:1 and 0.5:1, respectively (Figs. 4 Cand 5 C and Table II). The conductance of γ(α-βS508) and (α-βS508)(γ-βS481) channels with Na+ in the pipette was 3.2 and 7.9 picosiemens, respectively. We could not measure accurately the unitary currents of γ(α-βS508) channels with Li+ because of its small magnitude. Until now, the presence of the α subunit M2 was thought to be critical for expression of functional amiloride-sensitive Na+ channels. However, we have shown that the chimeric channels, composed of γ(α-βS508) and (α-βS508)(γ-βS481), both of which lacked the M2 from the α subunit, gave rise to functional channels. When compared with wild-type channels, the properties of γ(α-βS508) and γ(α-βS508)(γ-βS481) were different. Nonetheless, these channels still possessed the general basic properties of ENaC in that they were selective for Na+ and not for K+ (but INa+ > ILi+) and in that channel activity could still be inhibited by amiloride, although at slightly higher doses. Our observations indicate that the pore forming region of the α subunit is not a prerequisite for the expression of functional channels, since we have pores formed by the M2 of γ and β (γ(α-βS508)) and of β alone ((α-βS508)(γ-βS481)). These observations taken with those of the γ-β chimeras expressed with α subunits demonstrate that all three M2 regions can form functional pores, the properties of which depend on the subunit type(s) present. We also tested chimeras and combinations of subunits in which there were no sequences from the α subunit; none of them increased the Na+ permeability when injected in oocytes. Since the chimeras γ(α-βS508) and (α-βS508)(γ-βS481) contain the first 23 of α, this suggests that domains within this region of the α subunit are necessary for channel function. Most likely, they contain elements necessary for expression of channels either by promoting assembly of the subunits and/or of channels to the plasma membrane. There are other lines of evidence that support a potential role for the N-terminal region of the subunits participating in channel function. Residues preceding the first hydrophobic domain of acid-sensitive ion channel 2, a member of the ENaC/degenerin family of ion channels, have been shown to have a role in ion permeation, since mutations within this region dramatically increased the K+ permeability of these channels (16Coscoy S. de Weille J.R. Lingueglia E. Lazdunski M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 10129-10132Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). We were unable to address the contribution of the N-terminal region to channel function, because reverse chimeras comprising the N-terminal portion of β and the C-terminal of γ were all found to be nonfunctional. There have been numerous studies to demonstrate the putative roles of various residues in ion permeation and amiloride block (10Schild L. Schneeberger E. Gautschi I. Firsov D. J. Gen. Physiol. 1997; 109: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar, 11Kellenberger S. Gautschi I. Schild L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 4170-4175Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). However, none of these studies attempted to characterize if the various mutations altered channel kinetics or P o. One study performed on bovine α ENaC in lipid bilayers demonstrated that point mutations, in addition to altering amiloride sensitivity and ionic selectivity, increased channel P o (17Fuller C.M. Berdiev B.K. Shlyonsky V.G. Ismailov I.I. Benos D.J. Biophys. J. 1997; 72: 1622-1632Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Little is known about the structural domains that form or control the gating mechanism in these channels. ENaC exhibits characteristic slow and voltage independent kinetics with long openings and closures that can last several seconds. Previously, we had reported that channels formed by αβ or αγ displayed different kinetics (13Fyfe G.K. Canessa C.M. J. Gen. Physiol. 1998; 112: 423-432Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). αβ channels had long open times with brief closures and aP o close to 1, whereas αγ channels had shorter openings with a mean P o of approximately 0.5. These results suggested that domains within the γ subunit were responsible for the long closures. To address this question, we analyzed the kinetics of several γ-β chimeras that contained only part of the M2 from γ and also channels that did not have any sequences from γ M2 (α-βS508)(γ-βS481). The results showed that the M2 region of the subunits markedly influenced theP o and kinetics of channels. However, regardless of the subunit composition, all channels exhibited closures (although the τc was of different duration for each type of channel), indicating that the gating mechanism is not exclusively located in any one subunit but that most likely all three subunits contribute to it. The cytoplasmic region preceding M1 can also alter the kinetics of ENaC channels. Mutations of residues βG37S and αG95S in this region decrease the P o (18Gründer S. Firsov D. Chang S.S. Fowler-Jaeger N. Gautschi I. Schild L. Rossier B.C. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 899-907Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). However, it is unlikely that the N-terminal domain constitutes the gate. The amino acid sequence of the N-terminal domain is one of the least conserved among all members of the ENaC/degenerin family. In addition, a large segment from the N termini of α, β, and γ can be deleted without affecting activity. 2G. K. Fyfe, P. Zhang, and C. M. Canessa, unpublished observations. Most likely, β-Gly37 and α-Gly95 are not located in the gate, but their mutations produce an allosteric effect that alters the P o. On the other hand, we can rule out the gate being located at the level of the C terminus, because deletions of the C terminus of β and γ do not alter channel gating (13Fyfe G.K. Canessa C.M. J. Gen. Physiol. 1998; 112: 423-432Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). Amiloride blocks all of the channels belonging to the ENaC/degenerin family, although the affinities for amiloride vary widely among each of the individual members. Amiloride blocks the open channel by occluding the pore in a voltage-dependent manner; it senses approximately 15% of the membrane electrical field in wild-type ENaC. Therefore, the site of action of amiloride is most likely at the outer part of the pore, which is formed by the initial segment of M2 (10Schild L. Schneeberger E. Gautschi I. Firsov D. J. Gen. Physiol. 1997; 109: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar). The residues α-Ser583, β-Gly525, and γ-Gly537 all contribute to form a high affinity site (K i = 0.1 μm), maybe by forming a ring to accommodate the amiloride molecule. In agreement with this notion, our analysis of the amiloride affinity of α(γ-β) channels showed that the K i was influenced by the first segment of M2. However, the results also showed that, in addition, other factors contribute to define the amiloride affinity. αβ, αγ, and all four chimeric α(γ-β) channels have rings formed by identical residues, yet their amiloride affinities are different. Among the α(γ-β) channels, we found that the transition from low to high amiloride K i occurred between chimera (γ-βG529) (K i = 1.2 ± 0.04) and chimera (γ-βL537) (K i = 0.25 ± 0.01). The main difference between these chimeras is the presence of residues Gly529and Gly530 in β and of Ser541 and Cys542 in γ. To examine whether these two residues were responsible for conferring the differences in K i, we expressed the mutant channels αβG529S and αβG530C, expecting to obtain channels with low K i . Unfortunately, these mutants were not functional when expressed with α subunits alone but induced large currents when coexpressed with wild-type α and γ. The amiloride K i values of αβG529Sγ and αβG530Cγ were ∼0.1 μm, indicating that these residues, although essential for ion permeation, do not change the amiloride affinity. The observations suggest that, in addition to the composition of the side chains forming the putative binding site for amiloride, other surrounding amino acids influence the structure of the site and thus alter amiloride affinity. As expected from the small differences between αβ and αγ channels, all chimeric channels were permeable to Na+ and Li+ but not to K+. Experiments with γ-β chimeras showed that M2 changes the ILi+/Na+ratio from 1:1 (αβ channels) to 1.5:1 (αγ channels). The change was due to a progressive decrease in Na+ currents without a significant change in the magnitude of Li+ currents as indicated in Table II. These results show that the critical residues that determine selectivity and conductance are located in the initial segment of M2 as has recently been shown by Kellenberger et al. (11Kellenberger S. Gautschi I. Schild L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 4170-4175Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar, 19Kellenberger S. Hoffmann-Pochon N. Gautschi I. Schneeberger E. Schild L. J. Gen. Physiol. 1999; 114: 13-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). The corresponding residues in the three subunits (α-Gly587, β-Gly529, and γ-Ser541) and a ring of conserved serines (α-Ser589, β-Ser531, and γ-Ser543) form the putative selectivity filter. However, differences in ILi+/Na+ratio and in single channel conductance were observed among channels that had identical residues in the selectivity filter. For instance, pores formed only by α subunits (homomeric α channels) have ILi+/Na+of >1, whereas pores formed only by β subunits ((α-βS508)(γ-βS481)) have ILi+/Na+of <1. The same arguments presented for the amiloride affinity seem to apply for the determinants of selectivity in that other elements besides these residues affect the structure of the selectivity filter.

Previous work on the desensitization of G protein-coupled receptors has focused on the role of arrestin binding following receptor phosphorylation. We have examined the hypothesis that phosphorylation alone contributes to desensitization. In this study we demonstrate that for the Gq-coupled gastrin-releasing peptide receptor (GRP-R), phosphorylation by GRK2 to a stoichiometry of ∼1 mol PO4/mol GRP-R is sufficient in the absence of arrestin to reduce the rate of receptor catalyzed G protein activation by approximately 80%. Furthermore, GRP-Rs exposedin vivo to agonist are rapidly phosphorylated to a similar stoichiometry and are desensitized to a similar degree. Finally, the molecular mechanism for both in vitro GRK2-induced andin vivo agonist-induced desensitization is primarily a decrease in the maximum velocity (V max) for the catalysis of guanine nucleotide exchange by the GRP-R rather than a change in the affinity of the receptor for the αq or βγ subunits. Based on these results, we suggest that, for some G protein-coupled receptors, phosphorylation has a role in desensitization that is independent of arrestin. Previous work on the desensitization of G protein-coupled receptors has focused on the role of arrestin binding following receptor phosphorylation. Based on these results, we suggest that, for some G protein-coupled receptors, phosphorylation has a role in desensitization that is independent of arrestin. A. 1986; 83: 1174-1178Crossref PubMed Scopus (577) Google Scholar) methyl ester guanosine 5′-O-(3-thiotriphosphate) β,γ- methyleneadenosine 5′-triphosphate 3-(N-morpholinopropanesulfonic acid) Bombesin-like peptides elicit a variety of effects including mitogenesis, hormone secretion, and modulation of neuron firing rate (1Lebacq-Verheyden A.-M. Trepel J. Sausville E.A. Battey J.F. Sporn M. Roberts A. Handbook of Experimental Pharmacology. 95. Springer-Verlag, Berlin/Heidelberg1990: 71-124Google Scholar). These effects are transduced through a family of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs)1 including the gastrin-releasing peptide receptor (GRP-R) (2Spindel E.R. Giladi E. Brehm P. Goodman R.H. Segerson T.P. Mol. Endocrinol. 1990; 4: 1956-1963Crossref PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 3Kroog G.S. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. Med. Res. Rev. 1995; 15: 389-417Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). An agonist-activated GPCR catalyzes the exchange of guanine nucleotide on the α subunit of a heterotrimeric G protein leading to the formation of Gα-GTP. The subsequent dissociation of the heterotrimeric G protein leads to stimulation of signal transduction cascades mediated by the free Gα-GTP and Gβγ subunits (4Neer E.J. Cell. 1995; 80: 249-257Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1289) Google Scholar). In the bombesin receptor family, the activated GRP-R catalyzes guanine nucleotide exchange on Gαq (5Hellmich M.R. Battey J.F. Northup J.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 751-756Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) to activate effectors including phospholipase C-β (3Kroog G.S. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. Med. Res. Rev. 1995; 15: 389-417Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). Mechanisms to attenuate receptor signaling have evolved that limit the amplitude and/or duration of the signal transduction cascade(s) and are collectively referred to as “desensitization.” At the molecular level, desensitization may result from the degradation of ligand, from changes in receptor availability or activity, or from changes in the availability or activity of downstream effector molecules (6Grady E.F. Bohm S.K. Bunnett N.W. Am. J. Physiol. 1997; 273: G586-G601PubMed Google Scholar). Rhodopsin, which signals through transducin (Gt), and the β2-adrenergic receptor (β2AR), which signals through Gs, have been the most extensively studied GPCRs. In both cases, rapid agonist-induced receptor phosphorylation along with subsequent binding of an arrestin to the receptor play critical roles in receptor deactivation (7Hargrave P.A. McDowell J.H. FASEB J. 1992; 6: 2323-2331Crossref PubMed Scopus (234) Google Scholar, 8Lefkowitz R.J. Pitcher J. Krueger K. Daaka Y. Adv. Pharmacol. 1998; 42: 416-420Crossref PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar). Many other GPCRs are also known to be rapidly phosphorylated after addition of agonist (9Richardson R.M. Hosey M.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 22249-22255Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar,10Freedman N.J. Ament A.S. Oppermann M. Stoffel R.H. Exum S.T. Lefkowitz R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 17734-17743Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar), including the GRP-R (11Kroog G.S. Sainz E. Worland P.J. Akeson M.A. Benya R.V. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8217-8224Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Two classes of protein kinase have been implicated in agonist-induced GPCR phosphorylation: 1) the second messenger-dependent protein kinases A and C and 2) the second messenger independent kinases, called G protein-coupled receptor kinases (GRKs), including rhodopsin kinase (RK or GRK1) and the β-adrenergic receptor kinase 1 (βARK1 or GRK2) (12Premont R.T. Inglese J. Lefkowitz R.J. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 175-182Crossref PubMed Scopus (474) Google Scholar). Several GPCRs are known to be substrates for phosphorylation by GRKs in vitro (12Premont R.T. Inglese J. Lefkowitz R.J. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 175-182Crossref PubMed Scopus (474) Google Scholar). In vitro reconstitution systems have been used to evaluate the relative contributions of phosphorylation and arrestin for uncoupling. For rhodopsin, RK phosphorylation alone inhibits coupling to Gt, and the intrinsic inhibitory effects of phosphorylation on coupling are augmented by the addition of arrestin (13Wilden U. Hall S.W. Kuhn H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 1174-1178Crossref PubMed Scopus (577) Google Scholar, 14Krupnick J.G. Gurevich V.V. Benovic J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18125-18131Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). But for the β2AR, neither in vitrophosphorylation by βARK (GRK2) (15Benovic J.L. Kuhn H. Weyand I. Codina J. Caron M.G. Lefkowitz R.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8879-8882Crossref PubMed Scopus (372) Google Scholar, 16Pitcher J. Lohse M.J. Codina J. Caron M.G. Lefkowitz R.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3193-3197Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar) nor in vivodesensitization by agonist (17Keenan A.K. Cooney D. Holzhofer A. Dees C. Hekman M. FEBS Lett. 1987; 217: 287-291Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar) has a large effect on reconstituted receptor coupling. In contrast, phosphorylation of the β2AR by protein kinase A does deactivate the receptor (16Pitcher J. Lohse M.J. Codina J. Caron M.G. Lefkowitz R.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3193-3197Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar), as does addition of β-arrestin to βARK1-phosphorylated β2AR (18Lohse M.J. Andexinger S. Pitcher J. Trukawinski S. Codina J. Faure J.P. Caron M.G. Lefkowitz R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8558-8564Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This suggests that for the β2AR, GRK-induced phosphorylation serves primarily as a requisite for the binding of β-arrestin. Hence, receptor phosphorylation alone appears to have a variable effect upon coupling, depending upon assay conditions, receptor substrate, and protein kinase. But the β2AR is often viewed as the best model for GPCR desensitization because it is unclear whether data obtained from the unique environment of the visual system can be extrapolated to any other GPCR. The GRP-R undergoes rapid, agonist-induced desensitization (3Kroog G.S. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. Med. Res. Rev. 1995; 15: 389-417Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar), but the molecular mechanisms governing its desensitization are unknown. The GRP-R is rapidly phosphorylated in vivo by a protein kinase other than protein kinase C after exposure to bombesin (BN) (11Kroog G.S. Sainz E. Worland P.J. Akeson M.A. Benya R.V. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8217-8224Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar), but the role of phosphorylation in desensitization is undefined. Additionally, the molecular events resulting in desensitization of Gq-coupled receptors (such as the GRP-R) have been less well studied than for rhodopsin or the β2AR. It is unclear whether the mechanisms governing desensitization will be the same for receptors that use different cognate G protein(s). For example, for the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, which can couple to Gi/o and Gq, differences were found in the agonist- and GRK-induced phosphorylation and desensitization among and between Gi/o- and Gq-preferring receptor subtypes (9Richardson R.M. Hosey M.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 22249-22255Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19DebBurman S.K. Kunapuli P. Benovic J.L. Hosey M.M. Mol. Pharmacol. 1995; 47: 224-233PubMed Google Scholar). Therefore, to begin examining the molecular mechanisms involved in GRP-R desensitization, this study was undertaken to determine whether the GRP-R is a substrate in vitro for phosphorylation by a GRK, and if so, whether GRK phosphorylation effects GRP-R coupling. Sainz E. Worland P.J. Akeson M.A. Benya R.V. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8217-8224Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Reactions were stopped by removing PF medium, washing the cells twice with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, and adding 2% SDS/50 mm Tris, pH 8.0. Phosphorylated GRP-Rs were collected by immunoprecipitation as described above. Smigel M.D. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 11416-11423Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The plate was dried, and adenosine phosphates were visualized with an ultraviolet light source. The location of the 32P was determined by exposing the plate to x-ray film and quantitated with a PhosphorImager. Hirsch F.R. Martinet N. Vignaud J.-M. Mulshine J.L. Clinical and Biological Basis of Lung Cancer Prevention. Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, Switzerland1998: 143-156Crossref Google Scholar). For two-step phosphorylation/coupling assays, the total reaction volume was 100 μl. Ice-cold solution G was supplemented with other reagents as indicated. Reactions were initiated by adding GRP-R-containing membranes (treated with or without GRK2 in the phosphorylation assay) directly to the other components without any processing. Reaction velocities were determined by incubating samples at 30 °C and removing 10-μl aliquots at timed intervals. Aliquots were added to 4 ml of ice-cold solution S (20 mmTris-HCl, pH 8, 100 mm NaCl, 25 mmMgCl2) to terminate the reaction, and then samples were processed and radioactivity was quantitated as described (5Hellmich M.R. Battey J.F. Northup J.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 751-756Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Membranes containing the GRP-R were mixed on ice with Gβγ and solution G-supplemented as described in the figures. The mixture was prewarmed for 30 s at 30 °C, and then the reaction was initiated by addition of Gαq. Samples were incubated for the times indicated. In the presence of TMP, all reaction velocities were constant with time for at least 15 min, and the measurement of GTPγS binding at a single time point provided similar results to those obtained using rates obtained from progress curves (data not shown).V max and K m were determined using KaleidaGraph (Abelbeck Software) and fitting the data for initial velocities to a single site binding model. Samples were resolved on 10% Tris-Glycine polyacrylamide gels, transferred overnight onto nitrocellulose, and Western blotted using the pan-arrestin antibody F4C1 at a dilution of 1:250 using previously published methods (11Kroog G.S. Sainz E. Worland P.J. Akeson M.A. Benya R.V. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8217-8224Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). We first examined whether the GRP-R is a substrate for phosphorylation by a GRKin vitro. As our source of receptor, we chose to use urea-extracted membranes from transfected mammalian cells expressing high levels (∼550,000/cell) of a Myc epitope-tagged GRP-R (5Hellmich M.R. Battey J.F. Northup J.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 751-756Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 23Jian X. Sainz E. Clark W.A. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. Northup J.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 11573-11581Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar) because, in this system, the receptor is never removed from a biologically relevant membrane. Phospholipids have been shown to be important in regulation of GRK activity (32DebBurman S.K. Ptasienski J. Boetticher E. Lomasney J.W. Benovic J.L. Hosey M.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5742-5747Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar), and therefore a relevant membrane environment may be crucial for studying receptor phosphorylation and desensitization. Urea-extracted membranes from Sf9 cells infected with a GRP-R-containing baculovirus (22Kusui T. Hellmich M.R. Wang L.H. Evans R.L. Benya R.V. Battey J.F. Jensen R.T. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 8061-8075Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) were used for some experiments to confirm that there were no membrane-specific or Myc tag-dependent effects. Fig. 1 shows the in vitrophosphorylation of the Myc-tagged GRP-R by GRK2 (βARK1). There is no GRP-R phosphorylation in the absence of added GRK2 (lane 2), the GRP-R is a substrate for phosphorylation by GRK2 only in the presence of agonist (compare lanes 3 and 6 withlanes 4 and 7), and the GRK2-mediated GRP-R phosphorylation is markedly enhanced by the presence of Gβγ (compare lanes 3 and 6 with lane 8). The presence or absence of GTPγS has no effect on the phosphorylation reaction (compare lanes 3 and 4 with lanes 6 and 7), suggesting that there is no effect of endogenous Gα subunits. These results are consistent with previous data on the requirements for phosphorylation of GPCRs by GRK2 (33Haga K. Haga T. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 2222-2227Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In the presence of 300 nm bovine brain Gβγ, maximum phosphorylation (of 7.2 nm GRP-R) in a 30-min assay occurred with 300 nm GRK2, and the stoichiometry of GRK2-dependent phosphorylation was ∼0.9 mol PO4/mol GRP-R detectable by antagonist binding (data not shown). To study the effect of phosphorylation on coupling to G proteins, a two-step phosphorylation-coupling procedure was performed. In these experiments, 7 m urea-extracted GRP-Rs (expressed in either membrane environment) were first incubated with 150 nm bombesin in the presence or absence of GRK2 for 30 min. Bovine retinal β1γ1 was used to enhance phosphorylation. In the second step, the receptors were incubated in the presence of G protein subunits (Gαq and Gβ1γ1), GDP, and [S35]GTPγS, to assess GRP-R catalyzed guanine nucleotide exchange on Gαq. Cuttlefish retinal Gαq was utilized as a reporter for coupling because the GRP-R couples to this Gαq efficiently (5Hellmich M.R. Battey J.F. Northup J.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 751-756Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 23Jian X. Sainz E. Clark W.A. Jensen R.T. Battey J.F. Northup J.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 11573-11581Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar), and large quantities of cuttlefish Gαq can be prepared. Catalytic activity of the GRP-R without agonist was measured by adding an excess of ME (a pure GRP-R antagonist) to some of the reactions. The +ME condition is equivalent in the coupling assay to no added bombesin (data not shown). In Fig. 2, data are presented as a progress curve showing [S35]GTPγS binding as a function of time. In both mouse fibroblast (Fig. 2) and insect cell membranes (not shown), in vitro GRK-2-mediated phosphorylation of the GRP-R uncouples the receptor from Gq. All experiments performed using these conditions showed no detectable increase in the catalysis of [35S]GTPγS binding by bombesin for GRK2-treated receptors above the level catalyzed by either receptor preparation in the presence of antagonist. The rate of [35S]GTPγS binding catalyzed by control membranes in the presence of bombesin was significantly higher (2.9 ± .4 fold,n = 4) than the rate catalyzed by GRK2-treated membranes in the presence of bombesin. The uncoupling is not a result of the selective loss of correctly folded receptor because the number of antagonist binding sites are equivalent in both GRK2-treated and untreated conditions following a 30-min incubation (data not shown). Uncoupling requires the presence of ATP in the phosphorylation step because the replacement of ATP by the nonhydrolyzable analog AMP-PCP prevented GRK2-dependent uncoupling (data not shown). However, the continued presence of ATP is not required because the addition of AMP-PCP after the phosphorylation step did not prevent uncoupling (Fig. 2). Additionally, bombesin is needed in the phosphorylation step for GRK2 to uncouple the GRP-R because the addition of GRK2 without bombesin did not uncouple the GRP-R (data not shown). This implies that uncoupling requires the phosphorylation of the GRP-R because the receptor is not phosphorylated without the addition of agonist (Fig. 1). Finally, phosphorylation-induced uncoupling is a function of the stoichiometry of phosphorylation because partial uncoupling was seen with lower stoichiometry of phosphorylation (data not shown). To determine the stoichiometry of bombesin-stimulatedin vivo GRP-R phosphorylation, 5′ET4 cells were metabolically labe

To probe the structural and functional roles of active-site residues in the tryptophan synthase α2β2 complex from Salmonella typhimurium, we have determined the effects of mutation of His86 in the β subunit. His86 is located adjacent to β subunit Lys87, which forms an internal aldimine with the pyridoxal phosphate and catalyzes the abstraction of the α-proton of l-serine. The replacement of His86 by leucine (H86L) weakened pyridoxal phosphate binding ∼20-fold and abolished the circular dichroism signals of the bound coenzyme and of a reaction intermediate. Correlation of these results with previous crystal structures indicates that β-His86 plays a structural role in binding pyridoxal phosphate and in stabilizing the correct orientation of pyridoxal phosphate in the active site of the β subunit. The H86L mutation also altered the pH profiles of absorbance and fluorescence signals and shifted the pH optimum for the synthesis of l-tryptophan from pH 7.5 to 8.8. We propose that the interaction of His86 with the phosphate of pyridoxal phosphate and with Lys87 lowers the pK a of Lys87 in the wild-type α2β2complex and thereby facilitates catalysis by Lys87 in the physiological pH range. Multiple alignment of many sequences of several enzymes in this family (Fold type II) showed that the residue on the N-terminal side of the active-site Lys is His in the tryptophan synthase β subunit, Val inO-acetylserine sulfhydrylase, Phe or Tyr in threonine deaminase, Phe in threonine synthase, Val or Ile in cystathionine β-synthase, Phe in l-serine dehydratase, Phe or Ile ind-serine dehydratase, and Asn in 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate deaminase (see Electronic Appendix to Ref. 8Grishin N.V. Phillips M.A. Goldsmith E.J. Protein Sci. 1995; 4: 1291-1304Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar). This residue is located at the back of the coenzyme ring in the structures of tryptophan synthase (9Hyde C.C. Ahmed S.A. Padlan E.A. Miles E.W. Davies D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17857-17871Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), threonine deaminase (10Gallagher D.T. Gilliland G.L. Xiao G. Zondlo J. Fisher K.E. Chinchilla D. Eisenstein E. Jansonius J.N. J. Mol. Biol. 1998; 283: 121-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). The authors of the latter work suggested that this residue (Val40) may support the coenzyme ring, similar to the functions performed by Ala224 in aspartate aminotransferase (12Jansonius J.N. Vincent M.G. Jurnak F.A. McPherson A. Biological Macromolecules & Assemblies. 3. Manning J.M. Soda K. Ringe D. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 9661-9669Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar), which is classed in Fold type IV (8Grishin N.V. Phillips M.A. Goldsmith E.J. Protein Sci. 1995; 4: 1291-1304Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar). Investigations of the effects of mutagenesis of Leu201 utilizing biochemical (15Kishimoto K. Yoshimura T. Esaki N. Sugio S. Manning J.M. Soda K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1995; 117: 691-696Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar) and crystallographic (16Sugio S. Kashima A. Kishimoto K. Peisach D. Petsko G.A. Ringe D. Yoshimura T. Esaki N. Protein Eng. 1998; 11: 613-619Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar) methods support the proposal that Leu201 plays a crucial role in the transamination reaction by keeping the pyridoxyl ring in the proper location without disturbing its oscillating motion. The reaction of l-Ser with the β subunit proceeds through a series of PLP intermediates (Fig. 1 A): thegem-diamine intermediate (E-GD), the external aldimine ofl-Ser (E-Ser), and the external aldimine of aminoacrylate (E-AA). E-AA reacts with indole to form a quinonoid intermediate (E-Q); protonation of E-Q yields the external aldimine of thel-Trp (E-Trp). In the absence of added indole, E-Ser and E-AA accumulate. The equilibrium distribution of E-Ser and E-AA is affected by pH, temperature, monovalent cations, and allosteric ligands (17Peracchi A. Bettati S. Mozzarelli A. Rossi G.L. Miles E.W. Dunn M.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 1872-1880Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Recent crystal structures of enzyme-substrate intermediates formed by the tryptophan α2β2 complex provide further insight into the roles of His86 and of other active-site residues. The structure of E-Ser was obtained by cryocrystallography of a mutant (αD60N) tryptophan synthase α2β2complex in the presence of l-Ser (18Rhee S. Miles E.W. Mozzarelli A. Davies D.R. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 10653-10659Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1 B). The structure of E-AA was obtained with the wild-type α2β2 complex in the presence ofl-Ser and fluoroindole-3-propanol phosphate using a flow cell (19Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.-H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1 C). Both structures show that one nitrogen of His86 is within hydrogen-bonding distance of the phosphate of PLP and the hydroxyl group of Ser235. The phosphate of PLP also interacts with the hydroxyl group of Ser235 and with the carbonyl oxygens of Ser235and of three glycine residues in the glycine-rich loop (residues 232–234). The primary difference between the two structures is that His86 can form a hydrogen bond with the ε-amino group of Lys87 (3.09 Å) in the structure of E-AA, but is too far (3.8 Å) to form a stable hydrogen bond with Lys87 in the structure of E-Ser. However, because the temperature factor of the ε-amino group of Lys87 is high in both structures, this group undergoes fluctuations in its position. The presence of the hydrogen bond between His86 and Lys87 in E-AA (19Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.-H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar) is consistent with evidence from spectroscopic experiments that the abstracted α-proton of l-Ser is sequestered in a solvent-excluded site and possibly stored in a low barrier hydrogen bond (20Hur O. Leja C. Dunn M.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 7378-7386Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The interactions of His86 with PLP and with other residues in the active site would be expected to alter the pK a values of His86, Lys87, and the phosphate of PLP. Indeed, the 31P nuclear magnetic resonance chemical shift of the phosphate of the PLP, which is bound to the tryptophan synthase α2β2 complex and β2 subunit from E. coli, is pH-independent from pH 6.5 to 8.6, whereas the PLP 31P chemical shift of a model PLP derivative exhibits a pK a value of 6.23 (21Schnackerz K.D. Bartholmes P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1983; 111: 817-823Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The results suggest that the phosphate group of PLP is excluded from interaction with water and is fixed in its dianionic form by means of a salt bridge to a positively charged region of the active center, leading to a considerable lowering of the pK a value for the monoanion-dianion (21Schnackerz K.D. Bartholmes P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1983; 111: 817-823Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). This proposal is supported by the crystallographic results (Fig. 1, B and C) that show that His86 is within hydrogen-bonding distance of the phosphate of PLP. Interestingly, the 31P shift of PLP bound to d-serine dehydratase from E. coli is pH-dependent, with pK a ∼ 6.4 (22Schnackerz K.D. Feldmann K. Hull W.E. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 1536-1539Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar).d-Serine dehydratase is related in sequence to the tryptophan synthase β subunit, but has Ile117 at the position equivalent to His86 in the β subunit (see Electronic Appendix to Ref. 8Grishin N.V. Phillips M.A. Goldsmith E.J. Protein Sci. 1995; 4: 1291-1304Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar). These observations provide additional evidence that His86 in the β subunit stabilizes the phosphate of PLP as the dianion. Early studies of the effects of substitution of β subunit His86 by leucine (H86L) in the α2β2 complex concluded that His86 did not play an important role in catalysis or in substrate binding (23Miles E.W. Kawasaki H. Ahmed S.A. Morita H. Morita H. Nagata S. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 6280-6287Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Here we report more detailed investigations of the effects of pH on kinetic and spectroscopic properties of the H86L α2β2 complex. The results provide evidence that His86 facilitates catalysis by lowering the pK a of the catalytic residue Lys87 and also plays a structural role by binding and supporting the PLP coenzyme. Chem. 1989; 264: 6280-6287Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The α subunit was expressed and purified as described previously (26Jhee K.-H. Yang L. Ahmed S.A. McPhie P. Rowlett R. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 11417-11422Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Methods Enzymol. 1987; 142: 398-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). Chem. 1977; 252: 6594-6599Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The activity of tryptophan synthase in the β-replacement reaction (l-Ser + indole → l-Trp + H2O) was determined by a spectrophotometric assay (27Miles E.W. Bauerle R. Ahmed S.A. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 142: 398-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar) in the presence of 100 mm NaCl, 200 μm indole, and various concentrations of l-Ser. The activity in the β-elimination reaction (l-Ser → pyruvate + NH3) was determined with various concentrations ofl-Ser in the presence of 100 mm NaCl by a spectrophotometric assay coupled with lactic dehydrogenase (29Crawford I.P. Ito J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1964; 51: 390-397Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). One unit of activity in any reaction is the formation of 0.1 μmol of product in 20 min at 37 °C. Because the α subunit associates more weakly with the H86L β subunit than with the wild-type β subunit (23Miles E.W. Kawasaki H. Ahmed S.A. Morita H. Morita H. Nagata S. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 6280-6287Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), all assays were carried out in the presence of an ∼10-fold excess of α subunit. The maximal velocity (V) was determined by fitting the initial rate data to Equation 1, v=V·S/[Km+S](Eq. 1) where v is the initial rate and S is the concentration of l-serine in the presence of 0.2 mm indole. Absorption spectra were measured using a Hewlett-Packard 8452 diode array spectrophotometer. Fluorescence spectra were made using a Photon Technology International spectrofluorometer. The pH dependence of the absorption and fluorescence spectra was measured in the presence of 100 mml-Ser. Circular dichroism spectra were recorded on a Jasco J-715 spectropolarimeter in the absence and presence ofl-Ser (100 mm). The final concentration of the protein used for the spectroscopic measurements was 10 μm. All spectra were obtained in the presence of excess α subunit at 25 °C. The apparent dissociation constants of PLP for the wild-type and H86L α2β2 complexes were determined by measuring the activity of the apoenzymes in the β-replacement reaction (l-Ser + indole → l-Trp + H2O) in a reaction mixture containing 100 mml-Ser, 0.2 mm indole, 100 mm NaCl, 50 mm MBP buffer, and a 10-fold molar excess of α subunit at pH 7.3, 8.0, or 9.2 and at 37 °C. PLP concentrations were 0–1 μm for the wild-type enzyme and 0–30 μm for the H86L enzyme. The absorption spectrum of the H86L α2β2 complex in the absence ofl-Ser (Fig. 2) was similar to that of the wild-type α2β2 complex (spectrum not shown). However, the absorbance at 420 nm of the H86L α2β2 complex exhibited a small decrease at alkaline pH (Fig. 2, inset), which is not observed with the wild-type enzyme (17Peracchi A. Bettati S. Mozzarelli A. Rossi G.L. Miles E.W. Dunn M.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 1872-1880Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). The fluorescence spectra of the wild-type and H86L α2β2 complexes (Fig. 3 A) and plots of fluorescence at 510 nm versus pH (Fig. 3 B) also revealed differences between the two enzymes. Bettati S. Mozzarelli A. Rossi G.L. Miles E.W. Dunn M.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 1872-1880Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Rossi G.L. Miles E.W. Dunn M.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 1872-1880Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). The low wavelength peak of the H86L enzyme shifted from 340 to 320 nm with increasing pH. To further characterize the low wavelength peak of the H86L enzyme, fluorescence emission spectra (excitation at 335 nm) were recorded for the wild-type and H86L α2β2 complexes in the presence of l-Ser at three pH values (Fig. 4). The H86L enzyme, unlike the wild-type enzyme, exhibited a strong fluorescence emission at 400 nm at pH 7.6 in the presence of l-Ser. The intensity of this peak decreased with increasing pH. Ahmed S.A. McPhie P. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7944-7949Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). The PLP content was determined by a fluorometric method (37Adams E. Methods Enzymol. 1979; 62: 407-410Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). After dialysis for 8 h, the PLP content of the wild-type α2β2complex was unchanged, whereas the PLP content of the H86L α2β2 complex was reduced by 30%. Under the same conditions, the PLP content of the K87T α2β2 complex was reduced by 40% (36Banik U. Ahmed S.A. McPhie P. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7944-7949Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). The pH dependences of activity (V max) for the wild-type and H86L α2β2 complexes were determined for the β-elimination reaction (Fig. 6 A) and for the β-replacement reaction (Fig. 6 B). The pH profiles of the wild-type enzyme in the two reactions were very different. Although the activity was maximal at pH ∼7.5 in the β-replacement reaction as reported recently (38Ro H.-S. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31189-31194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar), the activity in the β-elimination reaction increased between pH 6.6 and 9.2. In contrast, the activity of the H86L enzyme was very low at pH 7 and increased markedly above pH 7.5 in both reactions. The H86L mutation shifted the maximum of the bell-shaped curve of V max versus pH in the β-replacement reaction from pH 7.5 to 8.8. Our studies of the effects of a mutation (H86L) in the active site of the β subunit of tryptophan synthase demonstrate that His86 stabilizes the PLP coenzyme and alters the pH dependence of the spectroscopic properties and of activity. Our findings that the H86L mutation increased the apparent dissociation constant for PLP (K d (PLP)) ∼18-fold (Table I) and increased the rate of removal of PLP by dialysis provide evidence that His86 plays a role in cofactor binding. This functional role is consistent with the crystallographic evidence that His86 interacts with the phosphate of PLP and with Ser235 in the Gly-rich loop and is located behind the PLP ring (Fig. 1, B and C). Dialysis has been used previously to compare the rate of PLP dissociation from the wild-type and K87T α2β2 complexes and to demonstrate that PLP is bound more weakly to the mutant enzyme (36Banik U. Ahmed S.A. McPhie P. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7944-7949Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). The results established the importance of the internal aldimine (E in Fig. 1 A) for tight binding of PLP. The interaction of the phosphate of PLP with a Gly-rich loop is a common feature of PLP enzymes in Fold types I, II, and IV (8Grishin N.V. Phillips M.A. Goldsmith E.J. Protein Sci. 1995; 4: 1291-1304Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar). Mutations (Gly to Asp) at either of two positions in the Gly-rich loop of d-serine dehydratase, an enzyme related to tryptophan synthase and in Fold type II, led to loss of activity and to a great increase in K d (PLP) (39Marceau M. McFall E. Lewis S.D. Shafer J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 16926-16933Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 40Marceau M. Lewis S.D. Shafer J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 16934-16941Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The results indicated that the mutant d-serine dehydratases bind PLP weakly, but do not hold the cofactor in a catalytically competent orientation. The tryptophan synthase β subunit is the only member of Fold type II that has His adjacent to the active-site Lys. Consequently, the interactions of His86 with the phosphate of PLP and Ser235, as shown in Fig. 1 (B andC), are likely to be features specific to tryptophan synthase that are important for binding PLP and for holding PLP in the catalytically competent orientation. Thus, mutation of His86 in tryptophan synthase has effects similar to those of mutation of Gly in the Gly-rich loop of d-serine dehydratase. The measured K d (PLP) is an apparent dissociation constant because it is determined from activity in the presence of l-Ser and indole. l-Ser may alter PLP binding in two ways: first by converting the internal aldimine to one or more external aldimines (Fig. 1 A) and second by inducing a conformational change that alters catalysis and increases subunit association (41Lane A.N. Paul C.H. Kirschner K. EMBO J. 1984; 3: 279-287Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). The occurrence of a conformational change triggered by reaction with l-Ser is supported by kinetic results (42Anderson K.S. Miles E.W. Johnson K.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 8020-8033Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 43Brzović P.S. Ngo K. Dunn M.F. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 3831-3839Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar) and by crystallographic results (19Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.-H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 44Rhee S. Parris K.D. Hyde C.C. Ahmed S.A. Miles E.W. Davies D.R. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 7664-7680Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar). A trueK d = 1 μm for PLP binding to the tryptophan synthase α2β2 complex fromE. coli has been determined by equilibrium dialysis (45Bartholmes P. Kirschner K. Gschwind H.P. Biochemistry. 1976; 15: 4712-4717Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Our finding that the apparent K d (∼0.2 μm in Table I) for the wild-type α2β2 complex obtained from activity in the presence of l-Ser and indole is lower than the trueK d = 1 μm demonstrates thatl-Ser does increase the affinity for PLP. The induced circular dichroism signal from enzyme-bound PLP has been proposed to largely originate from out-of-plane twisting of the internal aldimine double bond with respect to the pyridine ring of PLP (46Judd C.T. Ingraham L.L. J. Theor. Biol. 1978; 75: 503-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar). The loss in the H86L α2β2 complex of the circular dichroism signals that are observed in the wild-type α2β2 complex and in its reaction intermediate with l-Ser (Fig. 5) suggests that the double bond and the PLP ring have relaxed in the mutant enzyme. Several other mutant forms of the tryptophan synthase α2β2 complex exhibit optically active PLP coenzymes (35Kayastha A.M. Sawa Y. Nagata S. Kanzaki H. Miles E.W. Indian J. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 28: 352-357PubMed Google Scholar). The only exception observed previously is the K87T α2β2 complex, which has very weak circular dichroism at 400 nm (35Kayastha A.M. Sawa Y. Nagata S. Kanzaki H. Miles E.W. Indian J. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 28: 352-357PubMed Google Scholar). The results demonstrated the importance of the internal aldimine linkage (E in Fig. 1 A) for rigid or asymmetric binding of PLP (35Kayastha A.M. Sawa Y. Nagata S. Kanzaki H. Miles E.W. Indian J. Biochem. Biophys. 1991; 28: 352-357PubMed Google Scholar). Our new finding that His86is also needed for the rigid or asymmetric binding of PLP leads to the conclusion that multiple interactions are required for the proper orientation of PLP in the active site of the β subunit: the formation of an aldimine, interactions of the phosphate of PLP with residues 232–235 in the glycine-rich loop and with His86, and the location of His86 behind the PLP ring (Fig. 1). Our results show that mutation of β subunit His86 (H86L) altered the pH dependence of the absorption and fluorescence spectra of the tryptophan synthase α2β2 complex in the absence ofl-Ser (Figs. 2 (inset) and 3 (A andB)) and in the presence of l-Ser (Figs. 2, 3 (C and D), and 4) and altered the pH dependence of V max in the β-elimination and β-replacement reactions (Fig. 6, A and B, respectively). The H86L α2β2 complex formed very little E-Ser between pH 7 and 8 (Fig. 3 D) and had very low activity in either the β-elimination reaction (Fig. 6 A) or the β-replacement reaction (Fig. 6 B) between pH 7 and 8. Under the same conditions, the wild-type enzyme formed significant E-Ser (Fig. 3 D) and had significant activity (Fig. 6, A and B). Furthermore, the H86L α2β2 complex exhibited an intense fluorescence emission peak at 405 nm (excitation at 335 nm) at pH 7.6 and 8.0 that decreased in intensity at pH 9.3 (Fig. 4) and that was not seen with the wild-type enzyme. This emission peak is characteristic of PLP gem-diamines (47Schirch L.V. J. Biol. Chem. 1975; 250: 1939-1945Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) (E-GD in Fig. 1 A) and other PLP derivatives that have saturated C-4′ and sp 3character at C-4′ (31Johnson G.F. Tu J.I. Bartlett M.L. Graves D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1970; 245: 5560-5568Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 32Shaltiel S. Cortijo M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1970; 41: 594-600Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar). A gem-diamine intermediate has been detected previously in the reaction of the wild-type α2β2 tryptophan synthase complex with the intermediate analogues oxindolyl-l-alanine and 2,3-dihydro-l-tryptophan (48Roy M. Miles E.W. Phillips R.S. Dunn M.F. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 8661-8669Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). A novel derivative that has an emission maximum at 384 nm upon excitation at 340 nm is formed during the inactivation of a mutant (S377D) tryptophan synthase α2β2 complex (49Jhee K.-H. McPhie P. Ro H.-S. Miles E.W. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 14591-14604Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). In contrast, enolimine tautomers of Schiff bases exhibit maximal fluorescence near 500 nm upon excitation at the wavelength of maximal absorbance (320–350 nm) as reported for native phosphorylase (32Shaltiel S. Cortijo M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1970; 41: 594-600Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar). The combined spectroscopic results (FIG. 2, FIG. 3, FIG. 4) provide evidence that the H86L α2β2 complex reacts withl-Ser between pH 7 and 8 to form the gem-diamine intermediate (E-GD in Fig. 1 A) and that the conversion of E-GD to E-Ser is low under these conditions. The formation of a low level of E-Ser between pH 7 and 8 probably results from the low catalytic activity of the H86L α2β2 complex in β-elimination and β-replacement reactions in this pH range (Fig. 6). We now ask how the H86L mutation alters the catalytic properties. The presence of His86 behind the PLP ring in the wild-type enzyme may facilitate expulsion of Lys87 from thegem-diamine. In addition, His86 in the wild-type enzyme very likely alters the pK a of Lys87. His86, Lys87, and the phosphate of PLP are involved in a complex system of interactions with each other and with other residues in the β site (positions 232–235) in E-Ser (Fig. 1 B) and E-AA (Fig. 1 C). X-ray crystallography cannot assign the location of protons shared between these groups. However, 31P nuclear magnetic resonance studies of tryptophan synthase demonstrate that the PLP phosphate is a dianion and suggest that the dianion is stabilized by means of a salt bridge to a positively charged region of the active center, leading to a considerable lowering of the pK a value for the monoanion-dianion (21Schnackerz K.D. Bartholmes P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1983; 111: 817-823Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The crystallographic results (Fig. 1) suggest that His86 is the positively charged residue that forms an ion pair with the phosphate of PLP. This ion pair may stabilize the protonated His86, raise the pK a of His86, and reduce the pK a of the phosphate of PLP. The proximity of the protonated His86 to Lys87 may decrease the pK a of Lys87 and increase the ability of Lys87 to accept the α-proton of l-serine at neutral pH. This suggestion is supported by the observation that replacement of His86 by a neutral leucine residue (H86L) increased the pK a of Lys87 and shifted the pH activity profile (Fig. 6). Our recent investigations of the pH dependence of the kinetic parameters of the wild-type α2β2 complex in the β-replacement reaction provided evidence that Lys87has a pK a value of ∼7.2, which is much lower than the pK a of the ε-amino group of lysine in solution (∼10.5) (38Ro H.-S. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31189-31194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Our new results and interpretation of the crystallographic data provide a plausible explanation for the low pK a of Lys87 in the wild-type enzyme. The kinetic studies of the wild-type enzyme (38Ro H.-S. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31189-31194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar) also provided evidence that the decrease in activity in the β-replacement reaction at high pH (pK a = 8.3) (Fig. 6 B) is associated with a conformational change that yields an open form of the α2β2 complex. Interestingly, the pH profile of V max for the β-elimination reaction by the wild-type enzyme (Fig. 6 A), which has not been reported previously, was very different from that for the β-replacement reaction (Fig. 6 B). The β-elimination activity increased nearly linearly between pH 6.7 and 9.3. A plausible explanation is that the open form of the α2β2 complex formed at high pH has increased activity in the β-elimination reaction. We have proposed previously that the open form of the α2β2 complex, which is induced by mutation (50Ahmed S.A. Ruvinov S.B. Kayastha A.M. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21548-21557Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 51Ruvinov S.B. Ahmed S.A. McPhie P. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 17333-17338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 52Yang X.-J. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 22269-22272Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 53Yang L. Ahmed S.A. Rhee S. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7859-7866Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar), by solvents (54Ahmed S.A. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 16486-16492Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 55Ahmed S.A. McPhie P. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 29100-29106Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar), or by guanidine HCl or urea (56Fan Y.X. McPhie P. Miles E.W. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7881-7890Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar), has increased activity in the β-elimination reaction relative to activity in the β-replacement reaction because the E-AA intermediate is more accessible to hydrolysis by solvent water in the open form and because catalysis of the β-replacement reaction is less efficient in the open form. Our finding of increasing β-elimination activity with increasing pH is consistent with the previous conclusion that the open conformation is formed at high pH (38Ro H.-S. Miles E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31189-31194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). The H86L α2β2 complex also showed an almost linear increase in β-elimination activity between pH 7.5 and 9.3, but showed much lower activity at low pH than the wild-type enzyme. The decreased activity at low pH likely results from the increase in the pK a of the catalytic Lys87 caused by the mutation. In conclusion, our results provide evidence that His86 facilitates catalysis by altering the pK a of Lys87 and plays a structural role in binding and orienting the PLP coenzyme. We are grateful to Drs. Peter McPhie and Sangkee Rhee for helpful discussions and comments on the manuscript.
